pullRequest.body:
if the current toolchain has never been built on the CI, then spending
close to 4mins to look for each mathlib file is wasteful. So this checks
the existence a cache file for some file in `batteries` (I picked
`Batteries.WF`). If that is not present, then very likely the current
toolchain has not been tested yet, and we can skip the full `lake
cache`.

This speeds up mostly new `pr-testing` CI branches, or after a push to
the lean PR.

```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
```

maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by adomani.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10498217312/job/29082714957)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10498217312/job/29082715449)
This looks worth having, thanks for doing this! I have left one suggestion below; I will maintainer merge with that addressed.

You could also check for `Mathlib.Init`, now that this file exists. I think that would be even clearer, as that file is supposed to be imported everywhere. Can you test if that also works, and if yes, switch to it? Thanks!

I would be even bolder and look for a file further up the import chain: in 4 minutes, `lake build` has produced `olean`s probably around 100-200 files, so maybe testing for Mathlib.Data.Nat.Defs` is more efficient still.
Also, looking inside `Mathlib` has the advantage of speeding up PRs to `master` that normally would not have issues with files in dependencies.

Hmm, let‚Äôs see.

If the toolchain has changed (the use case I am aiming for), any file serves well.

If the toolchain hasn‚Äôt changed, but `Mathlib.Data.Nat.Defs` or a file it depends on has changed, then you‚Äôd be ignoring possible cache hits for all files that don't depend on `Mathlib.Data.Nat.Defs`, in particular all of `batteries`.

The tradeoffs seem unclear to me, so I'd stick to something simple. `Mathlib.Init` is nice and declarative.
I was wondering to this effect, and agree with the suggestion!
That's fine, but `Mathlib.init` will virtually never be changed, so PRs to mathlib master will almost never benefit from this PR.

Right, but that wasn‚Äôt the aim ‚Äì I was aiming for the cold cache case.

If you use a module somewhere in between, then some PRs benefit, other get slower, and it‚Äôs basically a game of chance.

Ideally `cache get` would dynamically stop fetching when 404s are returned, but that seems out of scope for it's current architecture.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(CI): skip full `cache get` if cache looks completely cold
